gpt-message.content: You are an expert in hardware design with a deep understanding of Verilog RTL codes. Now I want to train a large language model for code comment generation tasks specifically focused on Verilog RTL codes. And I want you to help me process the raw data, transforming it into suitable formats that can serve as inputs and outputs for the model.

Name of the module and its functionality is as follows: 
Module name: dff_sync.
Explanation: The dff_sync module is a D-type flip-flop with synchronous reset functionality implemented in Verilog. When the clock signal (clk) goes high (positive edge), if the reset signal is active, the output (o_q) is set to 0. If the reset is not active, the output (o_q) is set to the value of the input signal (i_d). There is also an inverted output (o_qb) which is complement of o_q. This kind of flip-flop is typically used in digital circuits to store data on the rising edge of the clock signal with the capability of being asynchronously reset to a known state.

Input and output ports and their explanation is as follows: 
Input ports: i_d, clk, reset. 
Explanation: 
- i_d: This is the data input of the D-type flip-flop. The value on this input is sampled and passed to the output (o_q) on a rising edge of the clock (clk) if the reset signal is inactive.
- clk: Clock input. It controls the timing of the data sampling and the output updates of the flip-flop. The positive edge of the clk signal triggers the flip-flop to either capture the input data (i_d) or reset the output (o_q) based on the state of the reset signal.
- reset: Synchronous reset input. When active, it causes the output (o_q) to reset to 0 on the rising edge of the clk signal. 

Output ports: o_q, o_qb. 
Explanation: 
- o_q: Main output of the D-type flip-flop. It either holds the value of the data input (i_d) captured on the last rising edge of the clk signal (if reset is inactive) or is reset to 0 (if reset is active).
- o_qb: Inverted output of the D-type flip-flop. It is always the complement of o_q.

Internal signals and their explanation is as follows: 
Internal signals: o_q. 
Explanation: 
- o_q: This is a register used to store the output value of the D-type flip-flop. It is directly dependent on the states of the input i_d and the reset signals on the positive edge of the clk input. If the reset is active, o_q is set to 0, otherwise, it captures and holds the value of i_d. This value is then used to provide the main output of the flip-flop and to derive the inverted output o_qb.
